{{Tone|date=May 2015}} {{Infobox television | show_name = 1992 | image = 1992 (TV series) logo.jpg | caption = | genre = [[Drama]]
[[Political drama]]
[[Political thriller]] | producer = | picture_format = [[1080i]] ([[High-definition television|HDTV]]) | country = Italy | language = [[Italian language|Italian]] | network = [[Sky Atlantic]]
[[Sky Cinema (Italy)|Sky Cinema]] | audio_format = 5.1-channel [[surround sound]] | camera = [[Single-camera setup|Single-camera]] | first_aired = {{Start date|2015|3|24}} | last_aired = | creator = [[Stefano Accorsi]]
Alessandro Fabbri
Ludovica Rampoldi
Stefano Sardo | starring = ''[[1992 (TV series)#Main cast and characters|See actors]]'' | narrated = | theme_music_composer = | composer = | num_seasons = 1-in production | editor = Wildside
[[Sky Italia]]
[[La7]] | num_episodes = 10 | distributor = [[Sky Italia]] | list_episodes = | executive_producer = Mario Gianani
Lorenzo Mieli | runtime = 60 minutes | company = Wildside - Sky Italia - BETA | followed_by = [[1993 (TV series)|1993]] | related = | website = http://skyatlantic.sky.it/skyatlantic/news/1992.html#_ }} '''''1992''''' is an [[Italian language|Italian]] [[political drama]] television series created by Alessandro Fabbri, Ludovica Rampoldi, Stefano Sardo and based on an idea by [[Stefano Accorsi]]. The first season, comprising ten episodes, premiered on March 24, 2015, on [[pay-tv]] [[Sky Italia]] channels [[Sky Atlantic]] and [[Sky Cinema (Italy)|Sky Cinema 1]]. Set in [[Rome]], [[Milan]] and different [[Italian cities]], the TV series offers a thrilling story following six people whose lives are intertwined with the rapidly changing political landscape in the early 1990s, during which Italy was gripped by the [[Mani Pulite|Clean Hands]] investigation into [[political corruption]]. Subsequently, this led to the end of the "First Republic" as well as the termination of several Italian political parties, who created the Italian democratic system after WWII. This controversial period in Italy resulted in the suicide of various political figures.{{cite web|url=http://nordicnoir.tv/news/1992-receives-warm-welcome/|title=‘1992’ receives warm welcome|website=Nordic Noir|accessdate=March 25, 2015}} The series was followed by ''[[1993 (TV series)|1993]]''. The series has been compared to ''[[House of Cards (U.S. TV series)|House of Cards]]'', ''[[The Sopranos]]'', and ''[[The West Wing]]''.{{cite web|author1=Mark Jones |author2=Jonathan Wright |author3=John Robinson |author4=Graeme Virtue |author5=Hannah J Davies |author6=Andrew Mueller |url=https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2015/mar/24/teens-dara-and-eds-great-big-adventure-1992|title=Tuesday’s best TV|website=The Guardian|accessdate=March 24, 2015}}{{cite web|author =Peter White|url=http://www.broadcastnow.co.uk/news/sky-arts-acquires-italian-political-thriller/5082751.article|title=Sky Arts acquires Italian political thriller|website=Broadcast Now|accessdate=February 5, 2015}} ==Series synopses== ===Season 1 (2015)=== In 1992, prosecutors in [[Milan]] launch the ''[[mani pulite]]'' investigation into [[political corruption in Italy]]. Leonardo Notte ([[Stefano Accorsi]]), a slick, self-serving advertising man who believes only in himself, schemes to profit from the unraveling scandal. Caught up in the investigation is Michele Mainaghi (Tommaso Ragno), a Milanese pharmaceutical magnate whose firm sold tainted blood that infected young police officer Luca Pastore (Domenico Diele) with [[HIV]]. Pastore, part of [[Antonio di Pietro]]'s investigative team, seeks revenge and teams up with Rocco Venturi (Alessandro Roja), another cop with a dark side. Meanwhile, Mainaghi's mistress, Veronica Castello ([[Miriam Leone]]), seeks out a career in television and returns to Notte after Mainaghi is disgraced. Upstanding [[Gulf War]] veteran Pietro Bosco ([[Guido Caprino]]) leaps into a fight and saves the life of a man who turns out to be one of the leaders of the new party [[Lega Nord]], quickly finding himself one of the party's parliamentary candidates. Veronica, initially intending to use him boost her TV career, instead falls in love with him; the two begin planning a life together. However, Pietro finds that he has to betray his friends and convictions if he wants to continue his political career and, most of all, build a family with Veronica. ==Episodes== ===Series 1 (2015)=== {{Episode table |background=#B60000 |overall=6 |season=5 |title=11 |director=19 |writer=42 |airdate=17 |episodes= {{Episode list/sublist|1992 (TV series) |EpisodeNumber=1 |EpisodeNumber2=1 |Title=Episode 1 |WrittenBy=Alessando Fabbri, Ludovica Rampoldi & Stefano Sardo |DirectedBy= Giuseppe Gagliardi |OriginalAirDate= {{Start date|2015|3|24}} |ShortSummary= Politician Mario Chiesa’s arrest ignites a nationwide scandal: Italy’s Tangentopoli. As the political fallout spreads across the country, we follow the intertwining lives and ambitions of six main characters. |LineColor=B60000 }} {{Episode list/sublist|1992 (TV series) |EpisodeNumber=2 |EpisodeNumber2=2 |Title=Episode 2 |WrittenBy=Alessando Fabbri, Ludovica Rampoldi & Stefano Sardo |DirectedBy= Giuseppe Gagliardi |OriginalAirDate= {{Start date|2015|3|24}} |ShortSummary= Showgirl Veronica’s tv career is on the verge of a major breakthrough, but the Tangentopoli affair seems to stop her in her track. Pietro, a Gulf war veteran, takes on the challenge of politics. |LineColor=B60000 }} {{Episode list/sublist|1992 (TV series) |EpisodeNumber=3 |EpisodeNumber2=3 |Title=Episode 3 |WrittenBy=Alessando Fabbri, Ludovica Rampoldi & Stefano Sardo |DirectedBy= Giuseppe Gagliardi |OriginalAirDate= {{Start date|2015|3|31}} |ShortSummary= Luca, a policeman, obtains the revenge he is seeking, but justice is another matter. Advertising man Leo finds himself under the threat of blackmail: someone has dug out some murky truth about his past. |LineColor=B60000 }} {{Episode list/sublist|1992 (TV series) |EpisodeNumber=4 |EpisodeNumber2=4 |Title=Episode 4 |WrittenBy=Alessando Fabbri, Ludovica Rampoldi & Stefano Sardo |DirectedBy= Giuseppe Gagliardi |OriginalAirDate= {{Start date|2015|3|31}} |ShortSummary= A new chance comes up for Veronica: her dreams again seem within reach. Bibi is confronted with a responsibility she had so far managed to elude. |LineColor=B60000 }} {{Episode list/sublist|1992 (TV series) |EpisodeNumber=5 |EpisodeNumber2=5 |Title=Episode 5 |WrittenBy=Alessando Fabbri, Ludovica Rampoldi & Stefano Sardo |DirectedBy= Giuseppe Gagliardi |OriginalAirDate= {{Start date|2015|4|7}} |ShortSummary= All main characters are faced with a major reboot in their lives: some have to take a step back to get started anew, whereas others suddenly get more than they had even dared to hope for. |LineColor=B60000 }} {{Episode list/sublist|1992 (TV series) |EpisodeNumber=6 |EpisodeNumber2=6 |Title=Episode 6 |WrittenBy=Alessando Fabbri, Ludovica Rampoldi & Stefano Sardo |DirectedBy= Giuseppe Gagliardi |OriginalAirDate= {{Start date|2015|4|7}} |ShortSummary= Luca gets close to Bibi’s projects for the powerful Mainaghi holding company. Leo undertakes a risky rise to power. In the background, the country is shaken by a new, devastating Mafia attack. |LineColor=B60000 }} {{Episode list/sublist|1992 (TV series) |EpisodeNumber=7 |EpisodeNumber2=7 |Title=Episode 7 |WrittenBy=Alessando Fabbri, Ludovica Rampoldi & Stefano Sardo |DirectedBy= Giuseppe Gagliardi |OriginalAirDate= {{Start date|2015|4|14}} |ShortSummary= In apparent summer calm, the old political establishment is hard at work on a major counterattack. Meanwhile, the main characters have to face the uneasy consequences of their ambitions. |LineColor=B60000 }} {{Episode list/sublist|1992 (TV series) |EpisodeNumber=8 |EpisodeNumber2=8 |Title=Episode 8 |WrittenBy=Alessando Fabbri, Ludovica Rampoldi & Stefano Sardo |DirectedBy= Giuseppe Gagliardi |OriginalAirDate= {{Start date|2015|4|14}} |ShortSummary= As prosecutor Di Pietro finds out, a spy hides within his Mani Pulite ("Clean Hands") investigation team. Leo is close to fulfilling his political hopes and dreams, but he undergoes a crisis of faith. |LineColor=B60000 }} {{Episode list/sublist|1992 (TV series) |EpisodeNumber=9 |EpisodeNumber2=9 |Title=Episode 9 |WrittenBy=Alessando Fabbri, Ludovica Rampoldi & Stefano Sardo |DirectedBy= Giuseppe Gagliardi |OriginalAirDate= {{Start date|2015|4|21}} |ShortSummary= Luca is ready to put everything at risk to get his revenge: his position within the Mani Pulite ("Clean Hands") task force is compromised. Pietro has to renege on his own self to save his relationship with Veronica. |LineColor=B60000 }} {{Episode list/sublist|1992 (TV series) |EpisodeNumber=10 |EpisodeNumber2=10 |Title=Episode 10 |WrittenBy=Alessando Fabbri, Ludovica Rampoldi & Stefano Sardo |DirectedBy= Giuseppe Gagliardi |OriginalAirDate= {{Start date|2015|4|21}} |ShortSummary= Di Pietro and the Mani Pulite team involve Prime minister Bettino Craxi as a prime suspect in their investigation. Our six main characters are confronted with extreme choices. It all builds up to a final judgement day: he who is willing to pay the most terrible price will win. |LineColor=B60000 }} }} ==Main cast and characters== * '''[[Stefano Accorsi]]''' as ''Leonardo Notte'', a marketing man with a murky past, coming back to haunt him just as 1992’s events seem to bring about the professional chance of a lifetime. Anonymous blackmail forces Leo to confront a morbid episode in his past that he had surgically removed from his memory. His glitzy, no-strings-attached lifestyle is turned upside down by the appearance of Viola, his hitherto unknown teenage daughter. As Leo tries to free himself from the shadows of the past, he stumbles into a revolutionary idea that could shape the future of his trade - and his own. * '''[[Guido Caprino]]''' as ''Pietro Bosco'', a 33-year-old veteran of the [[Gulf war]], finds himself elected in the Italian parliament, with the rising [[Lega Nord]] party. A gregarious rugby lover and beer drinker, he turns out to be the ultimate fish out of water in the political sphere. His only chances lie in finding the right mentor; thus, Pietro will put his career in the hands of a seasoned politician who will show him the ropes - certainly, at a price. * '''[[Domenico Diele]]''' as ''Luca Pastore'', a judicial police officer, works side by side with maverick prosecutor [[Antonio Di Pietro]]. Motivated by a personal quest for revenge, he is hard at work to solve the [[Tangentopoli]] conundrum. Investigations, arrests, interrogations. Under pressure and under menace. Because strong headwinds are blowing, and not just from outside the prosecutors’ offices. * '''[[Tea Falco]]''' as ''Beatrice "Bibi" Mainaghi''. Daughter of the aforementioned tycoon, is the black sheep in a power dynasty, but her life will take a new, radically unexpected turn in the wake of Tangentopoli. * '''[[Miriam Leone]]''' as ''Veronica Castello'', a showgirl on the fast track to fame. She needs it, physically, and is out to get it at all costs: the unconditional love of a prime time audience is the only viable conduit for her self-esteem. As the lover she has picked, powerful tycoon Michele Mainaghi, goes under in the investigations, Veronica briefly finds herself at a loss, then starts the search for a new, powerful pigmalione t position in the pecking order of the new powers that be. * '''[[Alessandro Roja]]''' as ''Rocco Venturi'', a young Roman police officer, also joining Antonio Di Pietro’s team of investigators. A sly look and his trademark fast talk would seem to put him as a natural leader in that team, but he will turn out to hide a totally different truth behind his gung-ho mask. Other characters: * '''[[Irene Casagrande]]''' as ''Viola Notte'' * '''[[Teco Celio]]''' as ''Gianni Bortolotti'' * '''[[Fabrizio Contri]]''' as ''[[Marcello Dell'Utri]]'' * '''[[Antonio Gerardi]]''' as ''[[Antonio Di Pietro]]'' * '''[[Gianfelice Imparato]]''' as ''Gaetano Nobile'' * '''[[Bebo Storti]]''' as ''Enrico Lodato'' * '''[[Elena Radonicich]]''' as ''Giulia Castello'' * '''[[Tommaso Ragno]]''' as ''Michele Mainaghi'' ==Reception== ===Italy ratings=== {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders" style="text-align:center; width:100%;" |- style="background:#e0e0e0; white-space:nowrap;" ! {{Infobox Currency | currency_name_in_local = Diner andorrà {{ca icon}} | image_1 =Andorran diner.jpg | image_title_1 = 10 andorran diners | using_countries = {{flag|Andorra}}1 | pegged_with=[[French franc]] (1:5) and [[Spanish peseta]] (1:100)2
[[euro]] (1:0.75) | subunit_ratio_1 = 1/100 | subunit_name_1 = cèntims | symbol = D. | symbol_subunit_1 = | used_coins = | used_banknotes = | issuing_authority = | issuing_authority_website = | printer = | printer_website = | mint= | mint_website = | footnotes = 1 Not legal tender. Intended for collectors only.
2 Informal exchange rate (never officially fixed) }} The '''Andorran diner''' (ADD) is a [[Commemorative coins of Andorra|commemorative currency]] issued in form of [[coin]]s intended for collectors and without a legal tender value. A diner is divided into 100 cèntims. The name ''diner'' (money in [[Catalan language|Catalan]]) is derived from the [[ancient Rome|Roman]] [[currency]] ''[[denarius]]''. The Servei d'Emissions de la Vegueria Episcopal has issued from 1977 onwards various series of diner denominated coins. Previously there were minor privately issued diner coinage (with no legal value). There have been silver, golder and bimetallic issues. The most commemorated topic is [[Charlemagne]].[http://www.wbcc-online.com/ctrys-a/andorra.html Worldwide Bi-Metallic Collectors Club: Andorran diner] The [[exchange rate]] was defined (informally) as 100 [[Spanish peseta|ESP]] (0.60 EUR) or 5 FRF (~125 ESP or 0.75 EUR) to one diner. But there is no bank or other authority where visitors to Andorra can change diners for [[euro]]s. It is only an informal relation. It is not possible to buy anything with diners in [[Andorra]]. It is not possible to open an account in diners. It is only an artificial currency to produce commemorative coins.[http://www.downies.com/Euro-Collections/Andorra/133/catmenu.aspx Euro Collections International Andorra Coins and Coin Sets] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131101051141/http://www.downies.com/Euro-Collections/Andorra/133/catmenu.aspx |date=November 1, 2013 }} In 1998 the [[General Council of the Valleys]] issued for the first time a series of diner denominated coins to commemorate the 250th anniversary of the ''[[Manual Digest]]''.[http://www.omnicoin.com/country/Andorra Some later uses of andorran diner] ==References== {{reflist}} ==See also== * [[Andorran euro coins]] {{dinar}} [[Category:Currencies of Andorra]] [[Category:Currencies of Europe]] {{Andorra-stub}}

{{Infobox song contest entry | song = {{flagicon|Luxembourg}} "C'est peut-être pas l'Amérique" | image = [[File:C'est peut-être pas l'Amérique.jpg|200px]] | caption = Single cover | year = 1981 | country = Luxembourg | artist = [[Jean-Claude Pascal]] | as = | with = | language = French | languages = | composer = Sophie Makhno,
[[Jean-Claude Pascal]],
Jean-Claude Petit | lyricist = Sophie Makhno,
[[Jean-Claude Pascal]],
Jean-Claude Petit | conductor = Joël Rocher | place = 11th | points = 41 | lyrics = [http://www.diggiloo.net/?1981lu from Diggiloo Thrush] | prev = Papa Pingouin | prev_link = Papa Pingouin | next = Cours après le temps | next_link = Cours après le temps }} {{Listen |filename=C'est peut-être pas l'Amérique.ogg |title="C'est peut-être pas l'Amérique" |description=Song excerpt |format=[[Ogg]] }} '''"C'est peut-être pas l'Amérique"''' ([[English language|English]] translation: "It May Not Be America") was the [[Luxembourg]]ish entry in the [[Eurovision Song Contest 1981]], performed in [[French language|French]] by [[France|French]] singer [[Jean-Claude Pascal]]. Pascal, along with Luxembourg/France's [[Anne Marie David]], Israel's [[Izhar Cohen]], Ireland's [[Johnny Logan (singer)|Johnny Logan]] and Sweden's [[Charlotte Perrelli]], was one of the very few Eurovision winners to return to the Contest since its inception some five decades ago; he had won in 1961 for Luxembourg singing "[[Nous les amoureux]]". "C'est peut-être pas l'Amérique" is in praise of [[Europe]] and its lifestyle, with Pascal singing that "America isn't everything" and explaining that he prefers the winds of southern [[France]] and the music he hears there. Pascal also recorded the song in German, entitled "Heut' ist vieles sehr amerikanisch" ("Today most things are very American"). The song was performed fourth on the night (following [[Germany]]'s [[Lena Valaitis]] with "[[Johnny Blue]]" and preceding [[Israel]]'s [[Hakol Over Habibi]] with "[[Halayla]]"). At the close of voting, it had received 41 points, placing 11th in a field of 20. It was succeeded as [[Luxembourg in the Eurovision Song Contest|Luxembourgish representative]] at the [[Eurovision Song Contest 1982|1982 Contest]] by [[Svetlana (singer)|Svetlana]] with "[[Cours après le temps]]". Jean-Claude Pascal died in 1992. ==Sources and external links== * [http://www.eurovision.tv/page/history/by-year/contest?event=297 Official Eurovision Song Contest site, history by year, 1981] * [http://www.diggiloo.net/?1981lu Detailed info & lyrics, The Diggiloo Thrush, "C'est peut-être pas l'Amérique"] * [https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0664270/ IMDB.com, Jean-Claude Pascal] {{Luxembourg in the Eurovision Song Contest}} {{Eurovision Song Contest 1981}} {{DEFAULTSORT:C'est peut-etre pas l'Amerique}} [[Category:Eurovision songs of Luxembourg]] [[Category:1981 songs]] {{luxembourg-stub}}

[[Archbishop of Esztergom]] | director = | fellowships = | associations = | area = [[Hungary]] | headquarters = [[Esztergom]], [[Hungary]] | founder = [[Stephen I of Hungary]] | founded_date = 1000 | founded_place = [[Esztergom]], [[Hungary]] | separated_from = | parent = | merger = | separations = | hospitals = | nursing_homes = | aid = | congregations = | members = 3,871,881 (2011) | ministers = | missionaries = | temples = | primary_schools = | secondary_schools = | tax_status = | tertiary = | other_names = | website = http://uj.katolikus.hu/ | footnotes = }} {{Catholic Church by country}} [[Image:Moegyh.svg|right|thumb|330px|Map of the Catholic dioceses of Hungary.]] The '''Catholic Church in Hungary''' ({{lang-hu|Magyar Katolikus Egyház}}) is part of the worldwide [[Catholic Church]], under the spiritual leadership of the [[Pope]] in [[Rome]]. There are around 3.842 million Catholics in [[Hungary]] — or 39% of the population (2011 census). The country is divided into 12 dioceses including 4 archdioceses. In addition, there is a [[territorial abbey]] and a separate [[sui juris]] [[particular Church]] for those who adhere to the [[Byzantine Rite]] known as the [[Hungarian Greek Catholic Church]]. The Church has been in decline in recent decades in Hungary; although the decline has not been as dramatic as in the [[Religion in the Czech Republic|Czech Republic]], it is nowadays only a plurality (the largest minority) in the country. *[[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Eger|Archdiocese of Eger]] with its [[suffragan diocese]]s: **[[Roman Catholic Diocese of Debrecen–Nyíregyháza|Diocese of Debrecen–Nyíregyháza]] **[[Roman Catholic Diocese of Vác|Diocese of Vác]] *[[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Esztergom-Budapest|Archdiocese of Esztergom-Budapest]] with its suffragan dioceses: **[[Roman Catholic Diocese of Győr|Diocese of Győr]] **[[Roman Catholic Diocese of Székesfehérvár|Diocese of Székesfehérvár]] *[[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Kalocsa-Kecskemét|Archdiocese of Kalocsa-Kecskemét]] with its suffragan dioceses: **[[Roman Catholic Diocese of Pécs|Diocese of Pécs]] **[[Roman Catholic Diocese of Szeged–Csanád|Diocese of Szeged–Csanád]] *[[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Veszprém|Archdiocese of Veszprém]] with its suffragan dioceses: **[[Roman Catholic Diocese of Kaposvár|Diocese of Kaposvár]] **[[Roman Catholic Diocese of Szombathely|Diocese of Szombathely]] Under Hungarian Greek Catholic Jurisdiction are: *[[Hungarian Greek Catholic Archeparchy of Hajdúdorog|Archeparchy of Hajdúdorog]] with its suffragan eparchies: **[[Hungarian Catholic Eparchy of Miskolc|Eparchy of Miskolc]] **[[Hungarian Greek Catholic Archeparchy of Nyiregyhaza|Eparchy of Nyiregyhaza]] Under the immediate jurisdiction of the [[Holy See]] in Rome are: * the revision.text:
{{Infobox film | name = Clando | image = | caption = | director = [[Jean-Marie Teno]] | producer = Jean Marie Teno | writer = Jean Marie Teno | narrator = | starring = Paulin Fodouop | music = | cinematography = [[Nurith Aviv]] | editing = Aurelie Ricard | distributor = Les Films Du Raphia
[[ZDF|ZDF - Zweites Deutsches Fernsehen]] | released = {{Film date|1996}} | runtime = 98 minutes | country = [[Cameroon]] | language = [[French language|French]] | budget = | gross = }} '''''Clando''''' is a [[1996 in film|1996]] drama film from [[Cameroon]] directed by Jean-Marie Teno.{{cite web|url=http://newsreel.org/video/CLANDO|title=Clando|publisher=California Newsreel|accessdate=17 July 2018}} Initially set in [[Douala]], the film explores the experiences of Anatole Sobgui (played by Paulin Fodouop){{cite web|url=http://www.bfi.org.uk/films-tv-people/4ce2b7eda4ad3|title=CLANDO (1996)|publisher=[[British Film Institute]]|accessdate=17 July 2018}}, a man who loses his job as a computer programmer and begins working as an unlicensed [[cab driver]] (or 'clando') who is arrested and tortured by a corrupt regime for printing anti-government leaflets. Left sexually and psychologically impotent by the experience, his life begins to deteriorate rapidly. He migrates to [[Cologne]] to find his former employer's son, Chamba. Here, he falls in love with a local, a political activist named Irene, who convinces him to return home to Cameroon.{{cite book|last=Henry|first=Freeman G.|title=GEO/GRAPHIES: Mapping the Imagination in French and Francophone Literature and Film|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=dzl6e6EL98oC|series=French Literature|volume=30|year=2003|publisher=[[Rodopi (publisher)|Rodopi]]|isbn=978-9042011540|pages=167–177}} ''Clando'' was Teno's first feature-length film.{{cite journal|last=Cham|first=Mbye|year=1998|title=African Cinema in the Nineties|journal=African Studies Quarterly|volume=2|issue=1|pages=47–51|issn=2152-2448|url=http://asq.africa.ufl.edu/previous-issues/volume-2/issue-1/}} It addresses issues around [[human migration|migration]] and [[political violence]] in Cameroon, and sharply criticizes the authoritarian leadership.{{cite web|url=http://www.rochester.edu/news/show.php?id=2081|title=Showing of Clando by Jean-Marie Teno, a Cameroonian filmmaker|date=21 March 2005|publisher=[[University of Rochester]]|accessdate=17 July 2018}}{{cite journal|last=Harrow|first=Kenneth W.|date=Spring 2011|title=Toward a New Paradigm of African Cinema|journal=Critical Interventions: Journal of African Art History and Visual Culture|volume=5|issue=8|page=221|issn=2326-411X|doi=10.1080/19301944.2011.10781411}} ==Cast== *Anatole Sobgui - Paulin Fodouop *Madeleine Sobgui - Henriette Fenda *Irene - Caroline Redl *Chamba Rigobert - Joseph Momo *Tchobe - Guillaume Nana ==References== {{reflist}} ==See also== {{IMDb title | 0126242 | Clando }} [[Category:1996 films]] [[Category:Cameroonian films]] [[Category:French-language films]] [[Category:Works about human migration]] {{Cameroon-film-stub}}

revision.text:
{{More references|date=December 2009}} '''European studies''' is a field of study offered by many academic [[college]]s and [[university|universities]] that focuses on current developments in [[European integration]].
Some programmes offer a social science or public administration curriculum focusing on developments in the European Union. These programmes usually include a combination of political science, EU public policy, [[European history]], [[European law]], [[economics]] and [[sociology]]. Other universities approach the subject in a broader manner, including topics like [[European culture]], [[European literature]] and [[European languages]]. While all programmes focus on the study of the European Union, they often cover national topics (in a comparative perspective) as well.
The subject combines [[humanities]] and [[social sciences]]. Disciplines that are involved in European studies include:
[[File:Diploma-licenciatura-estudos-europeus-universidade.jpg|thumb|The [[Bachelor's degree]] in [[European Studies]] from ''[[Universidade Aberta]]'' is [[interdisciplinarity|interdisciplinary]] and offers different [[Minor_(academic)|Minors]], namely in [[Economics]], [[Law]] and [[Sociology]]<ref>https://www2.uab.pt/guiainformativo/eng_detailcursos.php?curso=14v</ref>]]
{{columns-list|colwidth=30em| * [[Anthropology]] * [[Cultural studies]] * [[Economics]] * [[European languages]] * [[Geography]] * [[History]] * [[International relations]] * [[Law]] * [[Linguistics]] * [[Literature]] * [[Philosophy]] * [[Psychology]] * [[Political science]] * [[Public administration]] * [[Sociology]] }}
While European studies departments are obviously more common in Europe than elsewhere, there are departments dedicated to its study further afield, including in [[North America]], [[Asia]] and [[Australasia]].
== European studies associations == * [[UACES]] - the academic association for Contemporary European Studies * [[European Union Studies Association]] * [[Arbeitskreis Europäische Integration]]
==References== <references />
== External links == {{commons category}} {{Wikipedia books|Area studies}} * CIFE - [http://www.cife.eu//Default.aspx Centre international de formation européenne] * [https://europa-kolleg-hamburg.de/en/master-programme-european-legal-studies/at-a-glance/ Master in European and European Legal Studies] * [http://www.ie-ei.eu//Default.aspx Master in Advanced European and International Studies] * [http://www.eu-online-academy.org/ Master in EU Studies Online] * [https://www.zei.uni-bonn.de/education/ Master in European Studies - Governance and Regulation] ;Library guides for European studies * {{cite web |url=http://library.duke.edu/research/guides |publisher=Duke University Libraries |work=Research Guides |title=European Studies |location=USA }} * {{cite web |url=http://libguides.sais-jhu.edu/europe|publisher=Johns Hopkins University |work=Library Guides |title=European Studies |location=USA }} * {{cite web |url=http://guides.nyu.edu/Euro |publisher=New York University |work=Research Guides |title=European Studies |location=USA }} * {{cite web |title=History of Europe |url= http://www.nypl.org/collections/nypl-recommendations/guides?field_subject_taxonomy_value=604 |author=[[New York Public Library]] |location=USA |work=Research Guides }} + "[http://www.nypl.org/node/5636 Modern European History]"
{{Regional Cultural Studies}}

revision.text:
{{unreferenced|date=September 2014}} [[File:Green Ensign.svg|upright=1.3|thumb|Green Ensign after 1800]] [[File:Green Ensign (1701).svg|upright=1.3|thumb|Green Ensign circa 1701]] [[File:Green-Ensign 1783.jpg|upright=1.3|thumb|On a 1783 flag chart]] [[File:Green Ensign 1707 Canton.jpg|upright=1.3|thumb|Possible version of the Green Ensign with the flag of Great Britain in the canton]] The '''Green Ensign''' ({{Lang-ga|An Meirge Uaine}}) is a historical [[flag]] flown by some [[Ireland|Irish]] [[merchant vessel]]s from the 17th century to the early 20th century. The flag consists of a green field with a golden harp and a canton containing either the English Flag ([[St George's Cross]]) or a version of the [[Union Jack]].
This flag has appeared in these historical flag plates: *1685 Downham's Flag Chart *1700 Len's Flag Chart *1772 [[:File:Encyclopedie volume 6-145.png|French ''Encyclopédie'']] *1783 [[:File:Naval flags of the World 1783 (small).jpg|Bowles's Universal Display of the Naval Flags of all Nations]] *1799 Flags of all Nations *1848 Flaggen Aller Seefahrenden Nationen *1868 [[:File:Ireland. Johnson's new chart of national emblems, 1868.jpg|Johnson's new chart of national emblems]] *1889 Drawings of Flags of All Nations - British Admiralty *1917 National Geographic Flag Book
There remains a lively debate concerning whether the flag had any form of local official status within the British Isles or was simply an informal flag used by some merchant ships.
==See also== * [[Blue Ensign]] * [[Red Ensign]] * [[White Ensign]] * [[Green harp flag]]
==External links== *[http://flagspot.net/flags/ie-colon.html Green Ensign at FOTW site]
{{UKFlags}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox scientist | name = Gwen Fenton | image = Gwen Fenton.jpg | birth_name = | nationality = Australian | fields = Biology | workplaces = [[Australian Antarctic Division]] | alma_mater = [[University of Tasmania]] | known_for = First female Chief Scientist of the Australian Antarctic Division }}
'''Gwen Fenton''' is Chief Scientist of the [[Australian Antarctic Division]] and is the first woman to hold this position.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2015-12-11/dr-gwen-fenton-becomes-aads-first-female-chief-scientist/7022536|title=Gwen Fenton becomes AAD's first female chief scientist|date=2015-12-11|website=ABC News|language=en-AU|access-date=2016-08-15}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.antarctica.gov.au/news/2015/antarctic-division-appoints-first-female-chief-scientist|title=Antarctic Division appoints first female Chief Scientist|last=|first=|date=|website=antarctica.gov.au|publisher=Australian Antarctic Division|language=en-au|access-date=2016-08-05}}</ref> She discovered that the fish species, the [[Orange roughy]], can live to over 100 years old, leading to significant management changes of the species.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=http://www.antarctica.gov.au/magazine/2016-2020/issue-30-june-2016/people/career-challenges-shape-new-chief-scientist|title=Career challenges shape new Chief Scientist|website=www.antarctica.gov.au|language=en-au|access-date=2016-08-05}}</ref>
==Early life and education== Fenton grew up in Australia, the daughter of a zoologist and cosmic ray and aurora physicist.<ref name=":1" /> She completed a science degree with Honours at the [[University of Tasmania]] on coastal krill from south-eastern Australia and southern New Zealand. She continued her work at the University of Tasmania as part of a PhD focused on [[mysid|mysid crustaceans]], discovering three new genera and 12 new species, graduating in 1986.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://eprints.utas.edu.au/19936/7/whole_FentonGwenElizabeth1985_thesis_ex_pub_mat.pdf|title=Ecology and taxonomy of mysids (mysidacea : crustacea)|last=|first=|date=1985|website=|publisher=University of Tasmania|access-date=}}</ref>
==Career and impact== Fenton’s post-doctoral work at the University of Tasmania resulted in the development of a technique to age fish based on the radioactive decay of radium-226 to lead-210.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://frdc.com.au/knowledge/seafood_marketing/Documents/FRDC_Rep_92_41_Fenton.pdf|title=Age determination of oreo dory species by radiometric analysis|last=|first=|date=1996|website=frdc.com.au/|publisher=University of Tasmania|access-date=}}</ref> This revolutionized the understanding of the age of the important fishery species, orange roughy. Her work revealed that this species is extremely slow-growing, not maturing until between 20 and 25 years of age, with significant implications for sustainable management of catch limits for the species.<ref name=":0" /><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.ecosmagazine.com/?act=view_file&file_id=EC68p13.pdf|title=Methuselah of the deep|last=|first=|date=1991|website=ecosmagazine.com|publisher=Ecos|access-date=}}</ref>
Fenton joined the Tasmanian Government in marine environmental management and policy development in 1996. In her role she developed environmental monitoring programs for Tasmanian salmon farms, developed ballast water policy and provided advice on marine infrastructure developments.<ref name=":1" /> In 2003 she joined the Australian Antarctic Division as the Manager of Science Planning and Coordination.<ref name=":0" />
In 2015 Fenton became the first female Chief Scientist of the Australian Antarctic Division.<ref name=":0" /> Her role includes reviewing the Antarctic Science Strategic Plan and strengthening collaborations with East Antarctic partners such as China, India, Japan and France. She will also be working to ensure that the science program is ready to take advantage of the expanded capability that will come with the launch of Australia’s new [[icebreaker]] in 2020.
==References== {{Reflist|35em}}
== External links == * [http://www.antarctica.gov.au/science/meet-our-scientists/dr-gwen-fenton Gwen Fenton] at the [[Australian Antarctic Division]]
{{Authority control}}

revision.text:
The '''imperial election of 1208''' was an [[imperial election]] held to select the [[Holy Roman Emperor|emperor]] of the [[Holy Roman Empire]]. It took place in [[Frankfurt]] on November 11.<ref>{{cite book|title=Nagel Travel Guide Series: Germany|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=fNLXAAAAMAAJ|year=1965|publisher=McGraw-Hill}}</ref><ref name="(Firm)1960">{{cite book|author=Karl Baedeker (Firm)|title=Frankfurt and the Taunus: handbook for travellers|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Y_IZAQAAMAAJ|year=1960|publisher=K. Baedeker}}</ref>
As a result of the election, [[Otto IV, Holy Roman Emperor|Otto IV]] was unanimously named [[Holy Roman Emperor]].<ref name="Morris1991">{{cite book|author=Colin Morris|title=The Papal Monarchy: The Western Church from 1050 to 1250|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=S-DnCwAAQBAJ&pg=PA424|year=1991|publisher=Clarendon Press|isbn=978-0-19-826925-0|pages=424–}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}} [[Category:Elections in the Holy Roman Empire|1208]] [[Category:1208 in Europe]]

{{Refimprove|date=December 2009}} {{Infobox settlement | official_name = Lenzburg District | native_name = Bezirk Lenzburg | settlement_type = District | image_map = Karte Bezirk Lenzburg 2007.png | image_shield = Coat of arms of Lenzburg.svg | subdivision_type = [[Countries of the world|Country]] | subdivision_name = {{CHE}} | subdivision_type2 = [[Cantons of Switzerland|Canton]] | subdivision_name2 = {{Flag|Aargau}} | subdivision_type3 = Capital | subdivision_name3 = [[Lenzburg]] | area_total_km2 = 102.71 | area_footnotes = | population_as_of = {{Swiss populations Y|CH-AG}} | population_total = {{Swiss populations NC| CH-AG | B1907 }} | population_footnotes = | population_density_km2 = auto | timezone = [[Central European Time|CET]] | utc_offset = +1 | timezone_DST = [[Central European Summer Time|CEST]] | utc_offset_DST = +2 | blank_name_sec1 = Municipalities | blank_info_sec1 = 20 }} '''Lenzburg District''' is a district of the [[Canton of Aargau]] in [[Switzerland]], lying at the center of the canton. The district capital is the town of [[Lenzburg]]. It has a population of {{Swiss populations| CH-AG | B1907 }} (as of {{Swiss populations date|CH-AG}}).{{Swiss populations ref|CH-AG}} ==Geography== The Lenzburg district has an area, {{As of|2009|lc=on}}, of {{convert|102.71|km2|sqmi|sp=us}}. Of this area, {{convert|42.6|km2|sqmi|abbr=on}} or 41.5% is used for agricultural purposes, while {{convert|34.14|km2|sqmi|abbr=on}} or 33.2% is forested. Of the rest of the land, {{convert|20.16|km2|sqmi|abbr=on}} or 19.6% is settled (buildings or roads). ==Coat of arms== The [[blazon]] of the district [[coat of arms]] is ''Argent a Hurt.''[http://www.fotw.us/flags/ch-ag-lb.html Flags of the World.com] accessed 18-May-2010 ==Demographics== Bezirk Lenzburg has a population ({{As of|{{Swiss populations YM|CH-AG}}|lc=on}}) of {{Swiss populations|CH-AG|B1907}}.{{Swiss populations ref|CH-AG}} {{As of|2009|June}}, 19.7% of the population are foreign nationals.[http://www.ag.ch/staag/ Statistical Department of Canton Aargau -Bereich 01 -Bevölkerung] {{de icon}} accessed 20 January 2010 ==Economy== {{As of|2000|alt=In 2000}} there were 24,407 workers who lived in the district. Of these, 18,072 or about 74.0% of the residents worked outside the Lenzburg district while 14,959 people commuted into the district for work. There were a total of 21,294 jobs (of at least 6 hours per week) in the district.[http://www.ag.ch/staag/ Statistical Department of Canton Aargau-Bereich 11 Verkehr und Nachrichtenwesen] {{de icon}} accessed 21 January 2010 ==Religion== From the {{As of|2000|alt=2000 census}}, 12,952 or 27.9% were [[Roman Catholic]], while 23,937 or 51.6% belonged to the [[Swiss Reformed Church]]. Of the rest of the population, there were 45 individuals (or about 0.10% of the population) who belonged to the [[Christian Catholic Church of Switzerland|Christian Catholic]] faith.[http://www.ag.ch/staag/ Statistical Department of Canton Aargau - Aargauer Zahlen 2009] {{de icon}} accessed 20 January 2010 ==Education== Of the school age population ({{As of|2009|alt=in the 2008/2009 school year}}), there are 3,695 students attending [[Education in Switzerland#Primary|primary school]], there are 1,569 students attending [[Education in Switzerland#Secondary|secondary school]], there are 971 students attending [[Education in Switzerland#Tertiary|tertiary or university level schooling]], and there are 12 students who are seeking a job after school in the municipality. ==Municipalities== The district contains a total of 20 municipalities:

revision.text:
{{refimprove|date=June 2013}} {{Infobox military unit |unit_name= Liaison Squadron of 1st Air Command
''Eskadrila za vezu 1. vazduhoplovne komande'' |image= |caption= |dates=1952 – after 1959 |country= {{YUG}} |allegiance= |branch= [[Yugoslav Air Force]] |type= Squadron |role= Liaison |size= |command_structure= [[1st Air Command]] |current_commander= |garrison= [[Pančevo]] |ceremonial_chief= |colonel_of_the_regiment= |nickname= |patron= |motto= |colors= |march= |mascot= |battles= |anniversaries= |decorations= |battle_honours= |disbanded= after 1959 }} The '''Liaison Squadron of 1st Air Command''' (''[[Serbo-Croatian language|Serbo-Croatian]]: Eskadrila za vezu 1. vazduhoplovne komande / Ескадрила за везу 1. ваздухопловне команде'') was an aviation squadron of Yugoslav Air Force formed in 1952 at Pančevo airfield as '''Liaison Squadron of 1st Military district''' (''[[Serbo-Croatian language|Serbo-Croatian]]: Eskadrila za vezu 1. vojne oblasti / Ескадрила за везу 1. војне области''). Squadron was formed by order from December 17, 1951 on February 1, 1952 as part of 1st Military district . It was equipped with various training and liaison aircraft. Squadron was transformed into Liaison Squadron of 1st Air Command by 1959.Dimitrijević, Bojan. ''Jugoslovensko Ratno Vazduhoplovstvo 1942-1992''. Beograd, 2006, p. 365. It was disbanded after 1959, estimated 1961.Dimitrijević, Bojan. ''Jugoslovensko Ratno Vazduhoplovstvo 1942-1992''. Beograd, 2006, p. 366. ==Assignments== *[[1st Military district]] (1952–1959) *[[1st Air Command]] (1959-1961 ?) ==Previous designations== *Liaison Squadron of 1st Air Command (1952–1959) *Liaison Squadron of 1st Air Command (1959-1961 ?) ==Equipment== *[[Polikarpov Po-2]] (1952-1959) *[[Avro Anson|Avro Anson MkXI]] (1952-1959) *[[Kaproni Bulgarski KB-11 Fazan]] (1952-1959) *[[Ikarus Kurir]] (1959-1961 ?) ==References== [[Category:Yugoslav Air Force squadrons]] [[Category:Military units and formations established in 1952]] {{Yugoslavia-stub}} {{Europe-mil-stub}}

[[MHk 32 Liptovský Mikuláš]] | position = [[Forward (ice hockey)|Forward]] | height_cm = 185 | weight_kg = 91 | shoots = Left | birth_date = {{birth date and age|df=yes|1990|11|13}} | birth_place = [[Liptovský Mikuláš]], [[Slovakia]] | draft = | ntl_team = SVK | career_start = 2008 }} '''Lukáš Paukovček''' (born 13 November 1990) is a [[Slovakia|Slovak]] professional [[ice hockey]] player who currently plays professionally in Slovakia for [[HK Poprad]] of the [[Slovak Extraliga|Slovak Tipsport Liga]].[http://hkpoprad.sk/staronovym-centrom-kamzikov-bude-lukas-paukovcek/ Staronovým centrom Kamzíkov bude Lukáš Paukovček]{{Cite news|url=https://sport.sme.sk/c/20819231/lukas-paukovcek-sa-vracia-do-hk-poprad-maj-2018.html|title=Paukovček sa vracia do Popradu: V klube sa všetko zmenilo k lepšiemu|last=a.s.|first=Petit Press|work=sport.sme.sk|access-date=2018-06-19|language=sk}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.hockeyslovakia.sk/sk/article/lukas-paukovcek-novou-posilou-majstrovskej-nitry|title=Lukáš Paukovček novou posilou majstrovskej Nitry|website=HockeySlovakia.sk - oficiálny web slovenského hokeja|language=sk|access-date=2018-06-19}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{Commons}} *{{Eliteprospects}} {{DEFAULTSORT: Paukovček, Lukáš}} [[Category:1990 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People from Liptovský Mikuláš]] [[Category:Slovak ice hockey players]] [[Category:HK Poprad players]] [[Category:HK Nitra players]] {{slovakia-stub}}

{{Infobox musical artist | name = Magnetic Band | image = | caption = Gunnar Graps & Magnetic Band in 2003. | image_size = 250 | background = group_or_band | alias = | origin = [[Tallinn]] | genre = [[Heavy metal music|Heavy metal]], [[jazz rock]] | years_active = 1976–1983 | label = | associated_acts = [[Gunnar Graps Group|GGG]]
[[Mikronid]] | website = | current_members = Jüri Roosa, Erki Sepp | past_members = [[Gunnar Graps]], [[Vjatšeslav Kobrin]] }} '''Magnetic Band''' was an [[Estonia]]n [[Heavy metal music|metal-rock]] and [[jazz-rock]] band. ==History== Magnetic Band was formed in 1976 by [[Gunnar Graps]]. They played [[jazz-rock]], which had influences of [[reggae]] and [[funk]]-[[Soul music|soul]]. Later, after Graps graduated from [[Tallinn]] music school (in 1977), Magnetic Band was reformed and started to play metal-rock as well. Magnetic Band soon became one of the most popular heavy-music bands in [[Soviet Union]]. In 1980 Magnetic Band got first prize in the [[Tbilisi Rock Festival (1980)]]. They performed a mixture of jazz-rock, blues and funk and was noted for their instrumental mastership. In 1982, the [[Washington Post]] dedicated a whole page to Gunnar Graps and the Magnetic Band. In 1983, Magnetic Band got banned by Soviet authorities and was renamed to [[Gunnar Graps Group]] (GGG). GGG performed in Estonia and Soviet Union and was very popular until the end of decade. They performed until 1989. In 1997, the GGG reunited, although they performed only about once a month. ==External links== *[http://www.rockhell.spb.ru/musicians/magneticband/a1.shtml Magnetic Band's history (in Russian)] *[http://www.estmusic.com/index.php?0113372123210 Magnetic Band at EstMusic.com] {{Authority control}} [[Category:Estonian rock music groups]] [[Category:Musical groups established in 1976]] [[Category:Musical groups disestablished in 1983]] [[Category:1976 establishments in the Soviet Union]] [[Category:1976 establishments in Estonia]] {{Estonia-band-stub}}

<!--... Attention: THIS IS AN OUTLINE
part of the set of 740+ outlines listed at [[Portal:Contents/Outlines]].
Wikipedia outlines are a special type of list article. They make up one of Wikipedia's content navigation systems
See [[Wikipedia:Outlines]] for more details. Further improvements to this outline are on the way...--> {{double image|right|Flag of Norway.svg|188|Coat of arms of Norway.svg|78|The [[Flag of Norway]]|The [[Coat of arms of Norway]]}} [[File:Europe-Norway.svg|thumb|The location of [[Norway]]]] [[File:Map Norway political-geo.png|thumb|An enlargeable map of the [[Norway|Kingdom of Norway]]]] [[File:Norway rel96.jpg|thumb|An enlargeable map of continental [[Norway]]]]
''The following [[Outline (list)|outline]] provides an overview of, and topical guide to, the [[Norway|Kingdom of Norway]].''
'''Norway''' is a [[List of sovereign states|sovereign]] [[constitutional monarchy]], located principally in the western part of [[Scandinavia]] in [[Northern Europe]].<ref name=CIA_World_Factbook>{{cite web|date=July 2, 2009|url=https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/no.html|title=Norway|work=[[The World Factbook]]|publisher=[[United States]] [[Central Intelligence Agency]]|accessdate=July 23, 2009}}</ref> The country has land borders with [[Sweden]], [[Finland]], and [[Russia]], while the [[United Kingdom]] and the [[Faroe Islands]] lie to its west across the [[North Sea]] and [[Denmark]] to its south across the [[Skagerrak]] strait. The country's long and glaciated [[Atlantic Ocean|Atlantic]] coastline is deeply indented by [[fjord]]s, rising precipitously to high [[plateau]]x.
Norway also includes the [[Arctic]] island territories of [[Svalbard]] and [[Jan Mayen]]. Norwegian [[sovereignty]] over Svalbard is based upon the [[Spitsbergen Treaty]], but that treaty does not apply to Jan Mayen. [[Bouvet Island]] in the [[South Atlantic Ocean]] and [[Peter I Island]] and [[Queen Maud Land]] in [[Antarctica]] are external [[Dependent territory|dependencies]], but those three entities do not form part of the kingdom.
Since [[World War II]], Norway has experienced rapid economic growth, and is now amongst the wealthiest countries in the world.<ref>[[List of countries by GDP (nominal) per capita]]</ref><ref>[[List of countries by GDP (PPP) per capita]]</ref><ref>[[List of countries by current account balance]]</ref> Norway is the world's third largest oil exporter after [[Russia]] and [[Saudi Arabia]] and the [[petroleum industry]] accounts for around a quarter of GDP.<ref>[http://uk.reuters.com/article/oilRpt/idUKL0674675920070906 UPDATE 1-Statistics Norway raises '07 GDP outlook, cuts '08]</ref> It has also rich resources of gas fields, hydropower, [[fish]], forests, and minerals. Norway was the second largest exporter of seafood (in value, after China) in 2006.<ref>[http://www.globefish.org/filedownload.php?fileId=560 FAO Globefish global trends 2006]</ref> Other main industries include food processing, shipbuilding, metals, chemicals, mining and pulp and paper products. Norway has a [[Social welfare provision|Scandinavian welfare system]] and the largest capital reserve per capita of any nation.
Norway was ranked highest of all countries in [[Human Development Index|human development]] from 2001 to 2006, and came second in 2007 (to fellow [[Nordic countries|Nordic country]] [[Iceland]]).<ref>[[Human Development Index]]. Note that although Norway and Iceland's scores are the same to three decimal places, Iceland ranks higher when the decimal is expanded.</ref> It also rated the most peaceful country in the world in a 2007 survey by [[Global Peace Index]].<ref>{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/in_depth/6704767.stm | work=BBC News | title=Norway rated most peaceful nation | date=May 30, 2007 | accessdate=May 20, 2010}}</ref> It is a founding member of [[NATO]].
{{TOC limit|limit=2}}

revision.comment: Reverted 1 edit by [[Special:Contributions/197.231.200.41|197.231.200.41]] ([[User talk:197.231.200.41|talk]]) to last revision by 95.91.244.239. ([[WP:TW|TW]])
/* Communist */ I removed a name "Pulchny Niedźwiedź" from the list. It means literally "chubby bear" and there was no such person in the round table talks.
revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=May 2012}}
The '''Polish Round Table Talks''' took place in [[Warsaw]], Poland from 6 February to 5 April<ref>[http://quod.lib.umich.edu/j/jii/4750978.0006.301?rgn=main;view=fulltext The 1989 Polish Round Table Revisited: Making History. Brian Porter 1999] </ref> 1989. The government initiated the discussion with the banned trade union [[Solidarity (Polish trade union)|Solidarność]] and other opposition groups in an attempt to defuse growing social unrest.
==History== {{unreferenced|section|date=February 2015}} {{Eastern Bloc sidebar}} Following the factory strikes of the early 1980s and the subsequent formation of the (then still underground) Solidarity movement under the leadership of [[Lech Wałęsa]], the political situation in Poland started relaxing somewhat. Despite an attempt by the government to crack down on [[trade unionism]], the movement had gained too much momentum and it became impossible to hold off change anymore. In addition there was fear of a social explosion due to economic malaise and [[runaway inflation]] that had depressed Polish living standards and deepened public anger and frustration. By 1988 the authorities began serious talks with the opposition.
In September 1988, when a [[1988 Polish strikes|wave of strikes]] was coming to an end, a secret meeting was held which included Lech Wałęsa and [[Minister of Internal Affairs]] [[Czesław Kiszczak]]. They agreed on holding the so-called "Round Table" talks in the near future to plan out the course of action to be undertaken in the country. The Round Table talks began on 6 February 1989 at 2:23 pm CET. They included the ''solidarity opposition faction'' and the ''coalition government faction''. The talks were held in the Council of Ministers Office. The meetings were co-chaired by Wałęsa and Kiszczak.
The Polish communists, led by [[Wojciech Jaruzelski|General Jaruzelski]], hoped to co-opt prominent opposition leaders into the ruling group without making major changes in the political power structure. In reality, the talks radically altered the shape of the Polish government and society. The events in Poland precipitated and gave momentum to the fall of the entire European [[communist bloc]]; the [[Yalta arrangement]] collapsed soon after the events in Poland.
==Sessions== The sessions were divided into three main work groups: *Political reform workgroup *[[Union pluralism]] and party [[Pluralism (political philosophy)|pluralism]] workgroup *Economy and social issues workgroup
Specific issues were handled by these work groups, although meetings often ground to a halt. This was caused by a mutual distrust of the factions and an obvious unwillingness of the government faction to relinquish power. The most controversial questions were: *Pay raises and indexation *Future pluralist elections *The limit of the future president's competence *The limit of competence for the future [[Sejm]] and [[Senate of Poland|Senate]] *The access to [[mass media|mass communication media]] by opposition forces
A number of (radical) opposition organisations were quite opposed to the talks as they did not believe in the good intentions of the sitting government. Despite their fears a number of important documents were signed on 5 April, at the conclusion of the sessions. These documents became known as the Round Table Agreement.
==Results== An agreement ("Round Table Agreement") was signed on 4 April 1989. The most important demands, including those reflected in the [[April Novelization]], were: *Legalization of independent trade unions *The introduction of the office of President (thereby annulling the power of the Communist party general secretary), who would be elected to a 6-year term *The formation of a Senate
As a result, real political power was vested in a newly created [[bicameral legislature]] and in a president who would be the chief executive. Solidarność became a legitimate and legal political party. Free election to 35% of the seats in Sejm and an entirely free election to the [[Senate]] was assured.
The [[Contract Sejm|election of 4 June 1989]] brought a landslide victory to Solidarność: 99% of all the seats in the Senate and all of the 35% possible seats in Sejm. Jaruzelski, whose name was the only one the [[Communist Party]] allowed on the ballot for the presidency, won by just one vote in the National Assembly. The 65–35 division was soon abolished as well, after the first truly free Sejm elections.
The Round Table sessions were of momentous importance to the future political developments in Poland. They paved the way to a free and democratic Poland as well as the final abolition of communism in Poland.
==Participants== ===Opposition=== *[[Piotr Baumgart]] *[[Zbigniew Bujak]] *[[Andrzej Celiński]] *[[Rafał Czwojdrak]] *[[Jan Dworak]] *[[Marek Edelman]] *[[Władysław Frasyniuk]] *[[Bronisław Geremek]] *[[Ryszard Górny]] *[[Jarosław Jon]] *[[Jarosław Kaczyński]] *[[Lech Kaczyński]] *[[Krzysztof Kozłowski]] *[[Witysław Dys-Kulerski|Wiktor Kulerski]] *[[Zofia Kuratowska]] *[[Jacek Kuroń]] *[[Bogdan Lis]] *[[Kamila Majewska]] *[[Tadeusz Mazowiecki]] *[[Jacek Merkel]] *[[Adam Michnik]] *[[Jan Olszewski]] *[[Janusz Onyszkiewicz]] *[[Alojzy Pietrzyk]] *[[Jan Rokita]] *[[Janusz Sanocki]] *[[Krystyna Starczewska]] *[[Andrzej Stelmachowski]] *[[Janusz Szulc]] *[[Jerzy Turowicz]] *[[Lech Wałęsa]] *[[Andrzej Wielowieyski]]
===Communist=== *[[Władysław Baka]] *[[Włodzimierz Cimoszewicz]] *[[Marian Orzechowski]]<!--<ref name=kennedy>{{cite web|last=Kennedy|first=Michael D.|title=Negotiating revolution in Poland|url=http://www.ucis.pitt.edu/nceeer/2002-815-10g-Kennedy.pdf|work=NCEEER|year=2002|accessdate=14 July 2013}}</ref>--> *[[Józef Czyrek]] *[[Kazimierz Cypryniak]] *[[Wojciech Rygulski]] *[[Filip Czylok]] *[[Andrzej Gdula]] *[[Czesław Kiszczak]] *[[Mikołaj Kozakiewicz]] (representing [[United People's Party (Poland)|United People's Party]]) *[[Aleksander Kwaśniewski]] *[[Leszek Miller]] *[[Alfred Miodowicz]] (representing [[All-Poland Alliance of Trade Unions]]) *[[Andrzej Olechowski]] *[[Józef Oleksy]] *[[Janusz Reykowski]] *[[Marcin Święcicki]]
==Criticism== [[Image:Okragły Stół Pałac Prezydencki w Warszawie 05.JPG|thumb|300px|right|Original table displayed in [[Presidential Palace, Warsaw|Presidential Palace in Warsaw]]]] [[Andrzej Gwiazda]], who was one of the leaders of the so-called ''First Solidarity'' (August 1980 – December 1981), claims that the Round Table Agreement and the negotiations that took place before it at a Communist government's [[Ministry of the Interior and Administration (Poland)]] conference center (late 1988 and early 1989) in the village of [[Magdalenka, Masovian Voivodeship|Magdalenka]] had been arranged by Moscow. According to Gwiazda, who himself did not take part in the negotiations, the Soviets "carefully selected a group of opposition activists, who passed on as representatives of the whole [Polish] society, and made a deal with them".<ref>[http://www.se.pl/wydarzenia/kraj/okragy-sto-zosta-zaplanowany-w-moskwie_94674.html Okrągły Stół został zaplanowany w Moskwie, interview with Andrzej Gwiazda, Super Express, 08.04.2009]</ref>
This notion was supported by [[Anna Walentynowicz]], who in an interview given in 2005 stated that the Agreement was a "success of the Communists, not of the nation". According to Walentynowicz, [[Czesław Kiszczak]] and [[Wojciech Jaruzelski]], who initiated the negotiations, "safeguarded their own safety and (...) influence on the government". Walentynowicz claims that the talks were organized so that in the future, "no Communist criminal, murderer or thief would pay for their crimes".<ref>[http://www.se.pl/wydarzenia/kraj/okragy-sto-by-sukcesem-komunistow-nie-spoeczenstwa_88698.html Okrągły Stół był sukcesem komunistów, nie społeczeństwa, interview with Anna Walentynowicz, Super Express, 05.02.2009]</ref>
[[Antoni Macierewicz]] regards the negotiations and the agreement as a "classic Soviet plot of the secret services". In his opinion, both Kiszczak and Jaruzelski were "at every stage controlled by their Soviet overseers (...) and their autonomy was minimal". As Macierewicz said in February 2009, the Round Table was a "tactical success of the parts of the elites, but from the point of view of national interests of Poland, it was a failure".<ref>[http://www.gover.pl/news/szczegoly/guid/macierewicz-okragly-stol-to-przegrana Gover.pl, Polityka w sieci. Macierewicz: Okrągły Stół to przegrana, 06.-2.2009] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131029200636/http://www.gover.pl/news/szczegoly/guid/macierewicz-okragly-stol-to-przegrana |date=October 29, 2013 }}</ref>
Piotr Bączek of [[Gazeta Polska]] weekly wrote that in the mid-1980s, the so-called Communist ''Team of three'' ([[Jerzy Urban]], General [[Władysław Pożoga]] and [[Stanisław Ciosek]]), suggested that among opposition activists, "search for people, who are politically available" should be initiated, as "yesterday's opponent, drawn into the power, becomes a zealous ally".<ref>[http://niezalezna.pl/11539-4-czerwca-1989-r-jak-majstrowano-okragly-stol 4 czerwca 1989 r. – jak majstrowano Okrągły Stół by niezalezna.pl, 2011-06-04]</ref> In June 1987 [[Mieczysław Rakowski]], in a report handed to General Jaruzelski, wrote that a "change in the attitude towards the opposition must be initiated (...) Maybe, out of numerous oppositional fractions, one movement would be selected and allowed to participate in the governing", wrote Rakowski. Bączek's opinion is backed by Filip Musiał, a historian of Kraków's office of [[Institute of National Remembrance]]. In June 2008 Musiał stated that the ''Team of three'' was ordered to find a solution to a problem, which troubled Communist government of Poland. Economic situation of the country was worsening in the late 1980s, and the threat of social unrest was real. At the same time, the Communists did not want to relinquish power, so they prepared, in Musiał's words, "a political marketing operation".<ref>[http://fakty.interia.pl/prasa/tygodnik_solidarnosc/news/operacja-okraglego-stolu,1122671,3406 Operacja "okrągłego stołu", interview with Filip Musiał, interia.pl, June 5, 2008] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080613055913/http://fakty.interia.pl/prasa/tygodnik_solidarnosc/news/operacja-okraglego-stolu%2C1122671%2C3406 |date=June 13, 2008 }}</ref>
Musiał says that General Czesław Kiszczak himself decided which oppositional activists were "politically available" – the condition was that the candidates had to be supportive of "evolution" of the system, not its "radical rejection". Therefore, most opposition activists, who took part in the negotiations, were those who at different points of their lives were close to the "Marxist doctrine" or belonged to the Communist party. Furthermore, all participants were carefully scrutinized by the secret services. As a result, Poland was "the first Eastern Europe country, in which talks were initiated, but the last, in which completely free elections were organized, in the fall of 1991". [[Janusz Korwin-Mikke]] claims that one of the results of the Round Table agreement was that both sides pledged that "right-wing parties would never be allowed to rule",<ref>[http://www.fronda.pl/news/czytaj/tytul/korwin-mikke:_partie_prawicowe_ofiarami_pkw_15409 Korwin-Mikke: Partie prawicowe ofiarami PKW, fronda.pl, September 13, 2011]</ref> and [[Jan Olszewski]] said that "basic issues had been settled before [the talks], and the negotiations at the Round Table were about secondary matters".<ref>[http://salski.nowyekran.pl/post/16524,legenda-okraglego-stolu-klamstwem-zalozycielskim-iii-rp by Andy-aandy, June 3, 2011]</ref>

Adam Michnik and Lech Wałęsa drinking vodka with Czesław Kiszczak] * [http://quod.lib.umich.edu/j/jii/4750978.0006.301?rgn=main;view=fulltext The 1989 Polish Round Table Revisited: Making History Brian Porter 1999]

{{Infobox diocese | jurisdiction = Diocese | name = Cân Tho | latin = Dioecesis Canthoensis | local = Giáo phận Cần Thơ | image = Cathedrale Cần Thơ.jpg | image_size = 230px | image_alt = | caption = Cân Tho Cathedral | coat = <!-- Coat of arms file name (excluding File: prefix) --> | coat_size = | coat_alt = | flag = <!-- Flag file name (excluding File: prefix) --> | flag_size = | flag_alt = <!---- Locations ----> | country = {{flag|Vietnam}} | territory = | province = [[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Ho Chi Minh city|Ho Chi Minh]] | metropolitan = [[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Ho Chi Minh city|Ho Chi Minh]] | archdeaconries = | deaneries = | subdivisions = | coordinates = <!-- Use {{coord}} --> <!---- Statistics ----> | area_km2 = 12,214 | area_sqmi = <!-- Area in square miles, automatically converted --> | area_footnotes = | population = 4,836,900 | population_as_of = 2006 | catholics = 181,856 | catholics_percent = 3.8 | parishes = <!-- Number of parishes in the diocese --> | churches = <!-- Number of churches in the diocese --> | congregations = <!-- Number of congregations in the diocese --> | schools = <!-- Number of church supported schools in the diocese --> | members = <!-- Number of members in the diocese --> <!---- Information ----> | denomination = [[Roman Catholic]] | sui_iuris_church = [[Latin Church]] | rite = [[Roman Rite]] | established = | cathedral = Sacred Heart Cathedral in [[Cần Thơ]] | cocathedral = | patron = <!-- Patron saint(s) of the diocese (or archdiocese) --> | patron_title = <!-- Use to override the default label "Patron saint" --> | priests = <!-- Number of priests in the diocese --> <!---- Current leadership ----> | pope = {{Incumbent pope}} <!-- DO NOT CHANGE. This will update the Popes Automatically as they change --> | patriarch = | major_archbishop = | bishop = Stephanus Tri Buu Thiên | bishop_title = <!-- Type of ordinary: i.e. Bishop or Archbishop. Default is Bishop --> | metro_archbishop = [[Sede Vacante]] | coadjutor = | suffragans = <!-- List most senior first (usually reckoned by date of consecration); use | suffragan = for one --> | auxiliary_bishops = <!-- List most senior first (usually reckoned by date of consecration) --> | apostolic_admin = | vicar_general = | episcopal_vicar = | archdeacons = <!-- List most senior first (usually reckoned by date of first collation); use | archdeacon = for one--> | emeritus_bishops = <!-- List most senior first (usually reckoned by date of consecration) --> <!---- Map ----> | map = | map_size = | map_alt = | map_caption = <!---- Website ----> | website = [http://gpcantho.com/default.aspx Website of the Diocese] | footnotes = }} The '''diocese of Cần Thơ''' ({{lang-la|Dioecesis Canthoënsis}}) is a [[Roman Catholic]] diocese of [[Vietnam]].
The creation of the diocese in present form was declared November 24, 1960.
The diocese covers an area of {{convert|13257|km²|0|abbr=on}}, and is a [[suffragan diocese]] of the [[Archdiocese of Ho Chi Minh city]].
By 2004, the diocese of Cần Thơ had about 176,424 believers (3% of the population), 153 [[priest]]s and 131 [[parish]]es.<ref>[http://www.catholic-hierarchy.org/diocese/dcanv.html Catholic Hierarchy Directory]</ref>
[[Sacred Heart]] Cathedral in [[Cần Thơ]] has been assigned as the [[Cathedral]] of the [[diocese]].<ref>[http://www.gcatholic.org/churches/data/cathVN.htm#chk GCatholic.org]</ref>
==Bishops== *[[Emmanuel Lê Phong Thuận]] (June 20, 1990 – October 17, 2010) *[[Stephen Tri Bửu Thiên]] (2010–present)

revision.text:
'''Sales outsourcing''' is a way for companies to attract increased, high volumes of sales for their products or services by using a third party. The company typically uses outsourcing companies to improve sales volumes without links to the sales teams that carry out those campaigns. The company that undertakes the outsourcing will normally be paid based on the results they are able to generate, and therefore creates a mutually beneficial situation for both client and the outsourcing company.
== Background == Full 'sales outsourcing' is observed when companies have an external third party [[sales]] force. It is differentiated from [[Value-added re seller|value added reselling]] or [[Distributor (business)|distribution]] in that the [[business model]] can be based on shared risk, although there are models where the outsourcer is paid for all of their activity - just as with a hired [[direct sales]] force, but the outsourcer provides rapidity, flexibility and experience. Other names for sales outsourcing include 'indirect sales' and 'channel sales'.<ref>{{cite book|last=Anderson|first=E|title=Outsourcing the sales function: The real cost of field sales|year=2005|publisher=Thomson/South-western|location=Mason, Ohio|author2=Trickle }}</ref>
Full sales outsourcing is different from [[telemarketing]] in that it requires direct recruitment of sales personnel with specific backgrounds for each sales campaign. Usually the sales executives will be part of a team that may include telemarketing, [[marketing]], tools systems and methodologies as well as [[sales management]].
Sales [[outsourcing]] firms provide [[accountability]] regarding all sales results and activities while representing the brand of the client. For the end-customer, it usually appears as if the sales team sold the product themselves rather than the sales outsourcing firm. The outsourcing firm is, in essence, an extension of the client but is responsible for all operations associated with direct sales activities, often receiving sales engineering and initial product/service [[training]] support from the client.
== Purpose of indirect sales == The sole purpose of a contract sales organization is to provide sales resource to its clients, without taking title to their products. Sales outsourcing providers include [[manufacturers' representative]]s, contract sales organizations, sales agents or sales outsourcing consultants. One way of organising the sales effort, especially when product delivery is erratic, is to replace or supplement internal resources with [[wikt:function|functionality]] and expertise brought in from contract sales organisations.
Sales outsourcing is quite different from large-scale service outsourcing, which has its advantages but also requires pro-active contract and relationship management.<ref>{{cite book|last=Anderson|first=E|title=Outsourcing the sales function: The real cost of field sales|year=2005|publisher=Thomson/South-western|location=Mason, Ohio|author2=Trinkle }}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last=Novick|first=H. J.|title=Selling through independent reps|year=2000|publisher=AMACOM|location=New York, NY}}</ref> In addition to full sales outsourcing, many partial models are observed, particularly in large firms.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Rogers|first=B|title=An exploratory study of the make-or-buy decision in pharmaceutical sales|journal=Journal of Medical Marketing|year=2009|volume=9|issue=1|pages=11–20|doi=10.1057/jmm.2008.32}}</ref>
== Advantages ==
Sales outsourcing is expected to be cheaper than the fully loaded cost of employing salespeople, but calculating the cost comparison over time is far from straightforward. Nevertheless, replacing fixed costs with variable costs is attractive to budget-holders.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Rogers|first=B|title=An exploratory study of the make-or-buy decision in pharmaceutical sales|journal=Journal of Medical Marketing|year=2009|volume=9|issue=1|pages=11–20|doi=10.1057/jmm.2008.32}}</ref> However, unlike many forms of outsourcing, the advantages of sales outsourcing does not often come from saving costs but rather increasing [[revenue]] or providing speed of response or flexibility.
The [[business case]] for sales outsourcing should also include consideration of the cost of controlling the contract. Difficulty in measuring the link between sales activity and sales performance leads to a preference for employed salespeople.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Krafft|first=M |author2=Albers, S. |author3=Lal, R.|title=Relative Explanatory Power of Agency Theory and Transaction Cost Analysis in German Salesforces|journal=International Journal of Research in Marketing|year=2004|volume=21|issue=3|pages=265–283|doi=10.1016/j.ijresmar.2003.11.001}}</ref> However, the issues internally are often the same and the internal hire has many other corporate "distractions" that do not occur with external resources.
Companies may also choose sales outsourcing as a means of accessing the best sales skills.<ref>{{cite book|last=Anderson|first=E|title=Outsourcing the sales function: The real cost of field sales|year=2005|publisher=Thomson/South-western|location=Mason, Ohio|author2=Trinkle }}</ref> Although the [[pejorative]] term “rent-a-rep” is still used, there is some evidence that contractors are perceived as good performers against qualitative as well as quantitative performance criteria.<ref>{{cite book|last=Anderson|first=E|title=Outsourcing the sales function: The real cost of field sales|year=2005|publisher=Thomson/South-western|location=Mason, Ohio|author2=Trinkle }}</ref> Even so, the reputational risk of third parties handling customer relationships has been observed as a factor restricting sales outsourcing.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Weiss|first=A M |author2=Anderson E |author3=MacInnis D J|title=Reputation Management as a Motivation for Sales Structure Decisions|journal=Journal of Marketing|year=1999|volume=63|pages=74–89|doi=10.2307/1251975}}</ref> One could argue that an employee is often using a company to gain 2–3 years salary and experience whereas a sales outsourcing firm would usually be looking at a long term contract even though the staff may change during that time. So the aims of an outsourcer can be closely aligned with the aims and objectives of the contracting company.
A recent study has highlighted flexibility as an important driver for outsourcing sales.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Rogers|first=B|title=An exploratory study of the make-or-buy decision in pharmaceutical sales|journal=Journal of Medical Marketing|year=2009|volume=9|issue=1|pages=11–20|doi=10.1057/jmm.2008.32}}</ref> Uncertain business environments accentuate the need to turn sales resource on and off quickly. Industries and companies undergoing rapid change may need to avoid hiring and firing costs and risks.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Downey|first=J. M.|title=Risks of outsourcing - applying risk management to staffing methods|journal=Facilities|year=1995|volume=13|series=9/10|pages=38–44|doi=10.1108/02632779510095617}}</ref> Contract sales organizations can absorb employment risk, enabling their clients to respond to short-term opportunities or competitor activity (see [[Lean startup#Philosophy|Lean startup]]). However, an outsourcer may build in more of a premium to the rate or commission if excessive flexibility is required on a contract.
Contract sales organizations are growing in volume and influence, able to provide both tactical activity and long-term strategic support to their clients.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Rogers|first=B|title=Contract sales organizations (CSOs): making the transition from tactical resource to strategic partnering|journal=Journal of Medical Marketing|year=2008|volume=8|series=1|pages=39–47|doi=10.1057/palgrave.jmm.5050119}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.salespartnerships.com/resources/articles/contract-pharmaceutical-sales-pharma-landscape|title=Contract Pharmaceutical Sales: The Changing Pharma Landscape|date=2017-09-06|work=Sales Partnerships|access-date=2017-10-17|language=en-US}}</ref>
Speed of response is seen as a key reason to use an outsourcer. If a company was looking to enter a market it may take several months to recruit the local manager which then takes several months to find an office and build a team. With an outsourcer, a full working team can oftentimes be operational within a matter of days or weeks.<ref>{{citation|last=Poulter|first=Julian|title=Selling People Ltd|newspaper=Sales outsourcing alternatives|date=2005-05-21}}</ref>
Sales outsourcing can also be used as a [[market entry strategy]] and avoids [[permanent establishment]] risk.
==Indirect sales growth rate== The experience of many organizations over the past several years demonstrates that indirect channels can be critical to expanding market coverage. This has been particularly true in the [[electronics]], [[communications]] and [[high tech]] sectors.<ref>{{cite web|last=Chugg|first=Justin|title=What is a Master Agent?|url=http://www.telarus.com/why-telarus.php|publisher=Telecom Channel News|accessdate=10 March 2012}}</ref> For example, the indirect channel now accounts for 66 percent of overall technology sales, up from 53 percent in 1997.
==Examples of indirect sales companies== Some examples of communications companies who employ indirect sales forces to their internal sales efforts include: [[Airespring|AireSpring]], [[AT&T]], [[Comcast]],<ref>{{cite web|last=Oborn|first=Patrick|title=Comcast Solution Provider Program|url=http://www.telarus.com/carrier-information/comcast-business.html|publisher=Telecom Channel Association|accessdate=4 February 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130128124010/http://www.telarus.com/carrier-information/comcast-business.html|archivedate=28 January 2013|df=}}</ref> [[EarthLink|Earthlink Business]], [[Integra Telecom]], [[Level 3 Communications]],<ref>{{cite news|last=Holverson|first=Austin|title=Level 3 Debuts New Channel Partner Program; Introduces Tiered Structure and Enhanced Support Resources|url=http://www.telarus.com/industry/level-3-debuts-new-channel-partner-program;-introduces-tiered-structure-and-enhanced-support-resources.html|accessdate=4 February 2013|newspaper=Telecom Channel Updates|date=4 February 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130407082959/http://www.telarus.com/industry/level-3-debuts-new-channel-partner-program;-introduces-tiered-structure-and-enhanced-support-resources.html|archivedate=7 April 2013|df=}}</ref> [[Time Warner Cable]], [[TelePacific Communications|TelePacific]], [[tw telecom]], [[XO Communications]], and [[Windstream]].<ref>{{cite web|last=Chugg|first=Justin|title=Carriers in the Channel|url=http://www.telarus.com/carriers.html|publisher=Telecom Channel Updates|accessdate=6 March 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120226073857/http://www.telarus.com/carriers.html|archivedate=26 February 2012|df=}}</ref> Some top sales agencies who sell voice and data services for these carriers include [[Telarus]], based in [[Salt Lake City, Utah]], Intelisys, based in [[Petaluma, California]], and Telecom Brokerage Inc (TBI), based in [[Chicago|Chicago, Illinois]].<ref>{{cite news|last=Henderson|first=Khali|title=Comcast Agent Program|url=http://www.telarus.com/carrier-information/comcast-business.html|accessdate=14 March 2011|newspaper=Channel Partners|date=14 March 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110320204929/http://www.telarus.com/carrier-information/comcast-business.html|archivedate=20 March 2011|df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Chugg|first=Justin|title=Comcast Business Services Enters Into Master Agent Agreement with Telarus|url=http://www.telarus.com/news/comcast-business-services-enters-into-master-agent-agreement-with-telarus.html|accessdate=14 March 2011|newspaper=Telarus Industry News Briefs|date=14 March 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110321221607/http://www.telarus.com/news/comcast-business-services-enters-into-master-agent-agreement-with-telarus.html|archivedate=21 March 2011|df=}}</ref>

{{Infobox company | name = Slovak Telekom | logo = Telekom Logo 2013.svg | logo_size = 150px | parent = [[Deutsche Telekom]] | location = [[Bratislava]], [[Slovakia]] | area_served = [[Slovakia]] | industry = [[Telecommunication|Communications Services]] | homepage = {{URL|https://www.telekom.sk/}} |}} [[File:Slovak Telekom Logo.svg|200px|thumb|right|Slovak Telekom logo, February 2006-January 2012.]] [[File:ST logo.jpg|frame|right|Slovak Telecom logo, 2004-'06. By that time, it was one of the few Deutsche Telekom companies without the Telekom "T" in its logo.]]
'''Slovak Telekom''' is the convergent telco provider with the largest internet, fixed-line, digital TV, ICT and mobile services portfolio. The company is 100% owned by Deutsche Telekom AG.
The Slovak Telekom Group consists of the parent company Slovak Telekom a.s. and its subsidiaries Zoznam s.r.o., Zoznam Mobile s.r.o., Telekom Sec s.r.o., PosAm s.r.o., and DIGI SLOVAKIA s.r.o.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.telekom.sk/documents/10179/61107/ST_AR_2017_SVK_INTERACTIVE.pdf|title=Slovak Telekom Annual Report 2017 in Slovak – Slovak Telekom Ročná Správa 2017,|last=|first=|date=|website=|access-date=}}</ref>
== History == Until 1 July 2010, T-Mobile Slovensko was a mobile operator and a separate company owned by Slovak Telekom. After this date, T-Mobile was merged with the parent company Slovak Telekom.
Until 2 May 2005, T-Mobile Slovensko operated under the name EuroTel Bratislava.
== Services == As of April 2018, Slovak Telekom covers 93% of Slovak population with 4G mobile network,<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.telekom.sk/o-spolocnosti-telekom/press-centrum/tlacove-spravy/news-telekom-pokryva-lte-sietou-uz-93-populacie-slovenska-expanduje-aj-s-lte-a-a-volte|title=NEWS: Telekom pokrýva LTE sieťou už 93% populácie Slovenska, expanduje aj s LTE-A a VoLTE - Telekom|website=www.telekom.sk|access-date=2018-06-20}}</ref> introduced LTE-A technology to various towns in Slovakia, with speeds up to 375Mbps. It also introduced VoLTE (Voice over LTE) technology that allows calls directly in 4G, without need to switch to 3G and 2G.
Digital television service of Slovak Telekom, Magio TV, reached 600,000 customers in Q1 2018. The company also branched out to a new line of products for connected home and internet of things (IoT) and introduced a Magenta SmartHome brand.
Slovak Telekom had four strategic priorities in 2017: innovations, best connectivity, superior user experience and digital television.
'''Technologies:''' GSM, GPRS, EDGE, UMTS, HSDPA, LTE-A, VoLTE, Flash-OFDM, VDSL, FTTH
'''Prefixes:''' +421901; +421902, +421903, +421904, +421910, +421911, +421912, +421914
== Corporate Responsibility == Slovak Telekom promotes the value of social inclusiveness and empathy within the company and in public, through a long term support for the Slovak community of people with hearing impairment: supporting their entrepreneurship skills, better education of children through a program of visiting personal tutors, and by providing services of online interpreters.
== Communication == Since 2018, the new public face of the company in advertising campaigns is Bekim, a Slovak comedian and rapper, who started to use a wheelchair after he suffered an accident during a bicycle motocross competition in 2005. Bekim follows Peter Sagan, a famous Slovak professional road bicycle racer, who represented Slovak Telekom before him. The company’s slogan is “'''ÁNO'''” (“YES”) symbolizing a yell of an inventor who shouts “Yes” after coming up with some new technology. It also represents a defiant call that “Nothing is impossible”, “I say yes to a challenge” and “I will make it”.
==References== <references/>
==External links== *{{Official website|https://www.telekom.sk/}}
{{Deutsche Telekom}}

<!-- http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Garry%27s_Mod --> '''Zamba''' is the Supreme Creator-God of the [[Yaoundé]] people of the [[Cameroon]]s. According to the Yaoundé people, he made the Earth and all its creatures except human beings. He left that job to his four sons, Ngi (gorilla) the strong, N'Kokon (mantis) the wise, Otukut (lizard) the fool, and Wo (chimpanzee) the curious - and each made human beings in his own image, which is why we are the way we are.
==References==
